I can try. One thing to remember is that Ko-Mino kogai come in very odd
sizes, particularly very narrow ones. This kogai could not be made into a
kozuka because it was too narrow. Also, Ko-Mino pieces are carved directly
from the metal - no inlays. They did overlays, which do not pop out. The
mimikaki was cut off and joined to the base of the decorative panel - the
line is still there. The kogai was very early, and so much of the work is
indistinct. Still an interesting piece.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: alchemyst [mailto:alchemyst@...]
Sent: Saturday, November 01, 2003 1:43 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Naoshi fuchi



Gordon -

You were correct, I totally missed the kogai/fuchi connection.
(Easy to do when you only have 6 functional brain cells, or is
it five???)

Seriously, I can't imagine the metal working skill to bend
a kogai around into a fuchi without damage; crimping the metal,
popping the inlay, etc. Is there any way you can post better
pics of the fuchi? I'd love to see more detail of the work.

Thanks
Rich S
